etymology.description: 笨 (clumsy) + 脚/腳 (foot) = clumsy-footed; awkward in movement
etymology.interpretation: Combines an adjective of awkwardness with 'foot' to label someone unsteady or poorly coordinated on their feet. Often used for walking, running, or dancing that looks ungainly.
etymology.simplification: 腳 → 脚 via character simplification: the phonetic element 卻 was simplified to 却; 笨 unchanged.

examples.chinese: 他走路有点笨脚(他走路有點笨腳)。
examples.english: He’s a bit clumsy on his feet when he walks.

examples.chinese: 她跳舞时显得笨脚(她跳舞時顯得笨腳)。
下雨天路滑(下雨天路滑)，他更显得笨脚(他更顯得笨腳)。
examples.pinyin: Xiàyǔtiān lù huá, tā gèng xiǎnde bènjiǎo.
examples.english: On rainy days the road is slippery, and he seems even more unsteady on his feet.
